Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Quality Profile Modeling and Control with Applications in Tissue-engineered Scaffolds Fabrication

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this collaborative research is to develop a generic and systematic methodology for the modeling and control of quality profiles through the integration of advanced statistical techniques and expert knowledge of manufacturing processes. There is an increasingly common situation in industry practices where the quality of a process or product is characterized by a relationship between a response variable and an explanatory variable, called profiles. This research will build appropriate statistical models to characterize the effect of process parameters on the resulting quality profiles, and conduct process control, including spatial uniformity control and change detection, based on the process-profile models. A hierarchical modeling approach will be used in building the models, and advanced Bayesian approaches will be developed for model estimation and change detection. Expert knowledge of the process will be incorporated in the methodology development. The proposed approaches will be validated using degradation profiles in tissue-engineered scaffold fabrication processes.

The results of this research will fill the gap in the state-of-art manufacturing by providing a scientific base and a coherent set of quality engineering tools for quality profiles. A unique contribution of this work is the characterization of the effect of process parameters on quality profiles, which will establish a foundation for process design, monitoring and optimization based on quality profiles. Moreover, the application of the results in the control of degradation profiles in tissue-engineered scaffold fabrication will make it possible to produce tissue-engineered scaffold products that satisfy different requirements for human uses, and thus overcome critical barriers in developing engineered tissues/organs such as bone, liver, blood vessel, and heart valve to meet the vast need for tissue grafts in our nation.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is an increasingly common situation in industry practices where the quality of a process or product is characterized by a relationship between a response variable and an explanatory variable, called quality profiles. This project developed a series of generic and systematic methodologies for the modeling and control of quality profiles through the integration of advanced statistical techniques and expert knowledge of manufacturing processes. The proposed methodologies were demonstrated and validated using degradation profiles in tissue-engineered scaffold fabrication and optical profiles in low-emittance glass manufacturing.

Significant results of this project include: (1) Novel statistical approaches to model the relationship of process parameters in manufacturing and the resulting quality profiles with accommodation of expert knowledge on the manufacturing process. Conventional modeling approaches are purely data-driven, so their results are subject to measurement errors and outliers in data and may not be practically meaningful for the considered application. The constrained hierarchical modeling approach and constrained Gaussian process approach developed in this project solve this problem by incorporating various types of engineering expert knowledge (e.g., bound, monotonicity, concavity, censoring) in statistical modeling in the form of constraints. Essentially, they establish a convenient framework for accommodating expert knowledge in data analytics for accurate prediction and meaningful interpretation. (2) Systematic approaches for modeling and monitoring of optical profiles. These consist of a polynomial mixed-effect modeling approach for simple profiles, a piecewise polynomial mixed-effect modeling approach for complex profiles, a multivariate Gaussian process for multiple profiles measured at different locations, and a strategy for robust offline monitoring based on optical profiles. Practical issues in implementing those approaches are also investigated, such as segmentation of a profile with complex shape, selection of alternative models, problems associated with high within-profile correlation, and alternative strategies to monitor the data. Suitable solutions for the issues are provided.

Those results are reported in seven publications on high-quality journals such as Technometrics, Industrial and Systems Engineers (IISE) Transactions, Journal of Quality Technology, and IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering. Moreover, three of the papers were featured on the Industrial and Systems Engineering (ISE) Magazine. Two papers received the Best Application Paper Award and the Best Paper Award, respectively, of IISE Transactions which are designed to recognize significant work in the ISE profession.

A particular application area considered in this research is tissue-engineered scaffold fabrication, an emerging field in biofabrication aiming to develop engineered tissues/organs. As demonstrated in our case studies using real data from this application, the proposed approaches can reveal the relationship between process parameters and product performance and generate accurate predictions, which introduces data-driven process control into biofabrication. This will significantly boost the research on tissue-engineered scaffolds that satisfy different requirements for human uses, and thus overcome critical barriers to the development of engineered tissues/organs to meet the vast need for grafts. Another application of this research is low-emittance glass manufacturing. The low-emittance glass is made by coating regular glass with metal, metal oxide and metal nitride to modify its thermal and optical properties, and has become very popular for energy-efficient windows recently. This research provides systematic approaches to analyzing optical profile data and thus creates an upgraded toolset for quality control in this industry.

The interdisciplinary nature of this research across statistics, manufacturing, bioengineering and materials science provided students opportunities of multidisciplinary training. Three PhD students (with two female students) and one undergraduate participated in the project. Under the supervision of the PI, they conducted research, wrote papers, and presented their work at professional conferences such as the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS) annual conferences and IISE annual conferences. Research results of this project have been widely disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations of the PI and her students, and seminars given by the PI at the University of Texas at Arlington, Texas A&M University, City University of Hong Kong, University of Michigan, and Georgia Institute of Technology.


Last Modified: 07/08/2018
Modified by: Li Zeng
